questions.question:
Question 1: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress 
soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects 
tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this 
child?
questions.explanation:
Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. 
Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind 
pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF. Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, 
esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a 
diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray 
image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

questions.question:

questions.question: Question 3: What is the following image of a barium swallow suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance (distal 
narrowing), which is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the 
esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter 
(LES) on swallowing. The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The 
dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets 
accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the 
disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of 
dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak 
appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.

questions.question: Question 4: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis. 378 
Sold by @itachibot Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows: • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body • Elevated LES pressure Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the 
esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 
mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen. Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude ( 180 mmHg) contractions with an 
increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal. Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure ( 26 mmHg). 
Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

questions.question:
Question 5: A young woman was admitted with chief complaints of dysphagia since adulthood which 
worsened in the last three months followed by odynophagia, nausea, and vomiting of 
undigested food. Her barium swallow shows features suspicious of achalasia and she is 
advised to undergo esophageal manometry. Which of the following will not be seen?

options.d: Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body

questions.explanation:
There is increased esophageal baseline pressure in achalasia cardia. Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows: • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation • Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body • Elevated LES pressure • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to the gastric baseline pressure High-resolution manometry (HRM) is a gastrointestinal motility diagnostic system that measures 
intraluminal pressure activity in the gastrointestinal tract using a series of closely spaced pressure 
sensors. For a manometry system to be classified as high-resolution instead of classic, the 
pressure sensors must be spaced at most 1 cm apart.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is true about Chicago classification?

options.a: The classification is based on readings obtained by classic manometry
options.c: Type l achalasia exhibits panoesophageal pressurization pattern
options.d: Per oral endoscopic myotomy is the definitive treatment for type I achalasia

questions.explanation:
Type III achalasia in Chicago classification is also known as spastic achalasia. Achalasia cardia is a 
motility disorder of the esophagus in which the LES (lower esophageal sphincter) fails to relax 
due to loss of ganglion in the myenteric plexus. Chicago classification of esophageal motility divides achalasia cardia into 3 types. This 
classification is based on the readings obtained by high-resolution manometry (HRM). Type I achalasia cardia does not show pressurization pattern. Treatment options: • Pneumatic dilatation • Laparoscopic myotomy • POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy) 379 
Sold by @itachibot The definitive treatment for Achalasia is surgical myotomy (Hellers myotomy) + fundoplication.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed 
massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the 367 
Sold by @itachibot ■ Chicago classification, the patient has which type of achalasia?
questions.explanation:
The given features are suggestive of type III achalasia cardia. Type III achalasia cardia is characterised by massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of 
the distal esophagus. Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. 
During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is 
responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach, accompanied by the relaxation of the lower 
esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the 
LES causes an elevated median integrated relaxation pressure and a complete failure of 
peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to a megaesophagus.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was 
getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the 
following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical 
management is the first-line treatment modality. Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric 
plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, 
regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the 
oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s 
beak’. Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower 
esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) 
due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial 
fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the 
mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. 380 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve 
the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments 
and can be used while waiting for surgery. Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be 
candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is 
short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments. Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a 
balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low 
risk of esophageal perforation.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following esophageal carcinomas is most likely to develop in patients with 
long-standing achalasia cardia?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma. Achalasia is a premalignant condition. It becomes malignant due to long-standing, retained, 
undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation. Adenocarcinoma may also arise in the setting of achalasia but is less common as compared to 
SCC. Small cell carcinoma is a rare type of neuroendocrine esophageal carcinoma more common in the 
lower esophagus. It is very aggressive and the 5-year survival rate is 8%. Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing tumors of neuroendocrine cells that form in the GI tract, 
mainly in the rectum, small intestine, or appendix.

questions.question: Question 10: In which of the following conditions is peroral endoscopic myotomy done?
questions.explanation:
Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is used in achalasia cardia. 381 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment options: • Pneumatic dilatation • Laparoscopic myotomy • POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy) With the use of an operating endoscope, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid 
to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created. Through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter 
(LES), and cardia are visualized and divided, effectively performing an endoscopic myotomy. The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the 
patient to a 40%–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient presented with complaints of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw and 
dysphagia. It starts whenever he has ice cream and he takes sublingual nitroglycerin which 
provides him relief. He underwent manometry which showed simultaneous multi-peaked 
contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario with episodes triggered by cold foods and manometric findings are 
suggestive of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by 
spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It 
is more common in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain. Pathologically, there is marked 
hypertrophy of the circular muscles. It is often triggered by cold foods. It mimics symptoms of 
myocardial infarction and also shows improvement when sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. 
It causes smooth muscle relaxation of the esophagus. A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry (high-resolution 
manometry is preferred) is the gold standard test for diagnosis. In classic manometry, if there are 
simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration 
(>2.5 seconds) it is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm. 382 
Sold by @itachibot On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of 
DES. The distal contractile integral (DCI) is an index of contractile vigor in high-resolution 
manometry, calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal 
contraction. Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter - It is achalasia in evolution. Shows increased LES 
pressure but normal peristalsis. Nutcracker’s esophagus - It is the most common motility disorder of the esophagus. In 
conventional manometry, it shows a high-amplitude peristaltic contraction ( >180mmHg) and a 
longer duration of contraction (>7sec). In high-resolution manometry, a DCI > 8000mmHg is suggestive of nutcracker's esophagus.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient with dysphagia was evaluated with a barium swallow as given in the image. Which 
of the following is false regarding the management of this condition? 369 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Calcium channel blockers and nitrates are first line therapy
options.b: Pneumatic dilatation only provides short term relief
options.c: Myotomy of only the affected segment is done
options.d: Endoscopic botulinum injection is given when medical therapy is contraindicated

questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Myotomy involves the entire 
length of the affected segment along with a margin of several centimeters to the spastic region to 
prevent remnants of spasticity. First-line therapy is with calcium channel blockers and nitrates. Endoscopic botulinum toxin 
injection and pneumatic dilation are second-line therapies. Calcium-channel antagonists, 
vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Botulinum toxin injection is also considered an effective and low-risk procedure but for 
short-term symptom relief. Pneumatic dilation is targeted at the exact anatomic site of narrowing. Surgical treatment includes extended myotomy of the esophageal body or peroral endoscopic 
myotomy. Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a safe and effective treatment for patients, 
especially those who are refractory to medical therapy.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 72-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with complaints of difficulty 
swallowing and generalised weakness for 4 months. Peripheral smear revealed the following 
and an esophagography was done as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario with microcytic hypochromic anemia and characteristic esophagogram 
is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Plummer-Vinson syndrome/Paterson–Kelly syndrome has a triad of: • Post-cricoid webs • Dysphagia • Iron-deficiency anemia The webs are made up of fibrovascular stroma and esophageal epithelium. Glossitis, angular 
stomatitis, koilonychia are also associated with this condition. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic-hypochromic blood picture and barium 
esophagography or esophagogastroduodenoscopy(EGD) will help detect post-cricoid webs. Treatment includes correcting the iron-deficiency anemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. 
Esophageal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow 383 
Sold by @itachibot normal swallowing and passage of food. Complications include the risk of perforation during dilatation and also malignant transformation 
into squamous cell carcinoma. The image below shows endoscopic appearance of post-cricoid web.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 22-year-old male presented with intermittent dysphagia for the past 3 months. Barium 
swallow showed the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Schatzki’s ring. The barium swallow shows a thin circumferential ring in the distal esophagus, which is suggestive 
of Schatzki’s ring. Schatzki’s ring is a benign condition wherein there is a concentric, fibrous thickening and 
narrowing of the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ), with squamous epithelium above and 384 
Sold by @itachibot columnar cells below. Schatzki's ring is made up of mucosal and submucosal layers. It causes dysphagia and is 
associated with gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD). It is most commonly seen in the lower 
third of the esophagus. Treatment is endoscopic dilation with antireflux therapy and repeated dilation is often necessary. 
Persistent strictures should always raise suspicion for malignant disease. The image below shows endoscopic appearance of the Schatzki's ring.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 20-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of nonprogressive dysphagia for solids 
with no previous similar episodes. Barium swallow revealed fixed narrowing of the esophagus 
at the level of the aortic arch. CT angiography revealed the following. Which anomaly is most 
commonly seen in this condition? 371 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing 
extrinsic compression of the esophagus that is suggestive of dysphagia lusoria. In dysphagia lusoria, the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch 
instead of branching from the brachiocephalic artery. It then courses behind the esophagus to 
supply blood to the right arm. This causes pressure on the esophagus and results in dysphagia. It is diagnosed by CT angiography. A barium swallow shows fixed narrowing of the esophagus at 
the level of the aortic arch without mucosal abnormality. Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian 
artery. 385 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 65-year-old man presents with halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck. He 
also complained of persistent cough and regurgitation of food remnants shortly after 
consumption. He underwent a barium swallow which is given below. Which of the following 
is false regarding this condition? 372 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Occurs in the midline posteriorly and as sac enlarges lies on the left side
options.c: Dohlman’s procedure is indicated when size > 2-5 cm
options.d: Herniates through the thyropharyngeus and cricothyroid muscle

questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of a Zenker’s diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch. It is caused due 
to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the space between thyropharyngeus and 
cricopharyngeus. This space is known as Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts 
of the inferior constrictor in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is a pulsion diverticulum, formed due to increased intraluminal pressure forcing mucosa and 
submucosa to herniate. A small Zenker’s diverticulum < 2cm is managed by diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal 
myotomy. Large diverticulum > 2-5cm is treated by endoscopic diverticulopexy (Dohlman’s procedure) or 
by a diverticulectomy with cricopharyngeal myotomy.

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following is a true esophageal diverticulum?
questions.explanation:
Mid esophageal diverticula is a true diverticula. It involves all three layers of the esophageal wall 
such as mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis. Esophageal diverticula are herniations of the esophagus that extend into neighbouring structures. 
They occur as a result of primary motor disturbance or abnormality of the esophageal sphincters. They are classified based on their location into: • Zenker’s diverticulum (hypopharyngeal) • Mid esophageal (parabronchial) • Epiphrenic (supradiaphragmatic) 386 
Sold by @itachibot Epiphrenic and Zenker's diverticula are false diverticula involving herniation of only the mucosa 
and submucosa through the muscular layer of the esophagus. Midesophageal diverticula may be caused by traction on the esophagus from adjacent 
inflammation and fibrosis (classically tuberculosis). They are most common on the right side due 
to an overabundance of structures in the left mid-thoracic region. Zenker’s diverticulum: Epiphrenic diverticula as 1 and 2:

questions.question:
Question 18: A man presented with complaints of chest pain and a feeling of food getting stuck in the 
esophagus, after a meal. He has asthma and is under treatment. PPIs were prescribed but it 
did not resolve the problem so a barium swallow was done and showed the following. What is 
the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario and imaging findings are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. 387 
Sold by @itachibot Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal one-third of 
the esophagus. There is migration of eosinophils to the esophagus and they contribute to 
extensive tissue damage and inflammation. Clinical features include swallowing difficulty, food impaction, vomiting, and heartburn. Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus which is suggestive of 
eosinophilic esophagitis. These rings appear as stripes on the cat and is also known as the feline 
esophagus. Feline esophagus: The definitive diagnosis requires biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per 
high-power field. Treatment includes oral corticosteroids and immunotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 40-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department after the ingestion of a large 
amount of household cleaning liquid. She complained of a burning sensation in the throat 
and severe abdominal pain. She has a history of depression for the past 1 year. Which of the 
following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: It is a risk factor for esophageal carcinoma
options.b: Early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to assess the grade of mucosal injury
options.c: Prophylactic antibiotics improve the clinical outcome
options.d: Acids only cause superficial damage to the esophagus

questions.explanation:
Prophylactic antibiotics have not been shown to improve the clinical outcome of acute corrosive 
esophagitis and are not recommended. Corrosive esophagitis is caused due to the ingestion of alkali or acid and can be accidental or from 
attempted suicide. The injury caused by alkali ingestion is deeper due to the process of saponification of fats and 
dehydration. The injury caused by acids is more superficial because they cause coagulative 
necrosis with eschar formation, which prevents the deeper penetration of the acid. The acids also cause severe pylorospasm and therefore more gastric damage compared to alkali 
due to the accumulation of the contents in the antrum. Severe corrosive injury may lead to esophageal perforation, bleeding, stricture, and death. It is a 
risk factor for esophageal carcinoma. Therefore, early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to 
assess mucosal injuries even if there is no signs of oral injury. 388 
Sold by @itachibot Management of corrosive esophagitis: • Hemodynamic stabilization and management of patient's airway • Endoscopic evaluation of injuries • Surgical management includes laparotomy and • Esophageal stenting and jejunostomy for limited hemorrhage and superficial ulceration • Esophagogastric resection and jejunostomy for extensive necrosis.

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most common site for pill-induced esophagitis?
questions.explanation:
The most common site for pill-induced esophagitis is in the mid esophagus near the crossing of 
aorta or carina. These structures externally compress the esophagus and prevent the movement of 
the pills. Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This 
pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor 
pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming 
the pill. Drugs causing esophagitis are: • Doxycycline • Quinidine • Phenytoin • NSAIDs • Bisphosphonates

questions.question:
Question 21: Esophageal endoscopy of a patient reveals the presence of serpiginous ulcers. This finding 
indicates:
questions.explanation:
The image showing serpiginous ulcers in the otherwise normal mucosa of the distal esophagus is 
suggestive of cytomegaloviral esophagitis. 389 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with upper abdominal pain after 
having a heavy meal. On clinical examination, upper abdominal tenderness was noted. On 374 
Sold by @itachibot chest radiography widening of the mediastinum with pneumomediastinum was seen. What is 
the probable diagnosis?

options.d: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. In a perforated peptic ulcer, patients develop sudden onset severe generalized abdominal pain, 
tenderness, and board-like rigidity and an erect plain chest X-ray shows gas under the diaphragm 
(Option B). The foreign body in the esophagus can be asymptomatic or may present with 
perforation after ingestion. The radiopaque foreign body can be seen with a chest X-ray (Option 
C). Rupture of emphysematous bullae of the lung will lead to secondary pneumothorax, which 
manifests as chest pain and dyspnoea. A plain chest X-ray shows air in the thorax, and the 
mediastinum is pushed to the opposite side (Option D). Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus needs immediate diagnosis and intervention due to the 
higher mortality associated with it. The most common site of perforation is the lower esophagus 
towards the left esophageal cavity. Causes: • Iatrogenic perforation (most common) • Boerhaave's syndrome (spontaneous emetogenic perforation) • Sharp foreign body • Corrosive ingestion • Esophageal carcinoma It usually manifests as severe pain in the chest or abdomen after a meal or after a bout of 
drinking, commonly associated with dyspnoea. On clinical examination, there is rigidity and 
tenderness in the upper abdomen. The diagnosis is usually confirmed by a chest radiograph which 
shows pneumomediastinum, pneumoperitoneum, and pneumothorax. Subcutaneous emphysema 
can be seen in Boerhaave's syndrome. Patients with sepsis will have a fever, tachycardia and 
tachypnea. 390 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment includes adequate drainage, antibiotics, closure of the perforation site if possible and 
supportive measures.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a history of severe chest pain radiating to 
the back and difficulty in breathing following several episodes of vomiting. PR- 110bpm and 
BP- 80/50 mm of Hg. On examination, there is palpable crepitus over the chest wall. Which of 
the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Most common in lower third of esophagus
options.b: Iohexol is used as contrast agent
options.c: Cervical esophagostomy and gastrostomy is done in early presentation
options.d: Most common cause of mortality is mediastinitis

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario points to Boerhaave's syndrome. Primary closure is done in stable 
patients presenting within 24 hrs and not cervical esophagostomy with gastrostomy. Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused due to episodes of 
vomiting. During vomiting, the pressure in the esophagus rises rapidly and the esophagus 
ruptures at the weakest point. They usually have a history of heavy meal intake and alcohol abuse. Clinical features include Mackler's triad: • Retching • Chest pain • Subcutaneous emphysema The diagnosis is made by contrast esophagogram(iohexol) in unstable patients or 
contrast-enhanced CT scan, in stable patients. Treatment includes primary closure within 12 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. If the 
patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected and cervical esophagostomy is 
performed. A T-tube is placed into the esophagus along with appropriately located drains and a 
feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition. Most common cause of mortality in Boerhaave syndrome is mediastinitis (40% to 50%).

questions.question:
Question 24: A 47-year-old woman underwent endoscopy for the evaluation of dysphagia. After the 
procedure, she developed severe chest pain radiating to the back and respiratory distress. 
What is the initial investigation you will perform on this patient to identify the cause?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of esophageal perforation following endoscopy. The initial 
investigation that is performed in this condition is a contrast esophagogram which will show the 
extravasation of the contrast. Water-soluble contrast (iohexol) should be used instead of barium contrast to prevent 
barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum if there is perforation. If the esophagogram is normal, contrast-enhanced CT is useful in identifying the injury. If the 
radiological investigations are normal and suspicion of esophageal perforation is high, then 
endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following cases of esophageal perforation will you not manage surgically?

options.a: Crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion
options.b: Severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of vomiting
options.c: Septic shock due to pyothorax and mediastinitis on left side of lower esophagus
options.d: Epigastric pain radiating to the shoulder with air under the diaphragm

questions.explanation:
The patient with crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion most 
likely has perforation of the cervical esophagus. Instrumental perforations in the cervical 
esophagus are usually small and can nearly always be managed conservatively. 391 
Sold by @itachibot Esophageal perforation is mostly due to spontaneous or iatrogenic causes. Iatrogenic 
instrument-induced perforation is the most common cause of esophageal perforation and is most 
common in the cervical esophagus in the cricopharyngeal area. Clinical features include pain as the most common presentation. Crepitus may be present. 
Hamman sign is heard during auscultation which is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with 
the heartbeat. Investigations include: • X-ray chest • CT scan • Esophagogram • Thoracentesis • Serum amylase level may be raised. Treatment is primary closure within 24 hours of injury and conservative treatment in selected 
cases. Complications of esophageal perforation are pneumothorax and empyema (most common in the 
left side of the chest and bilateral in 10% of cases). Option B: The patient with severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of 
vomiting most likely has Boerhaave syndrome which affects the lower third of the esophagus and 
requires primary closure within 24 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. Option C: Patients presenting with septic shock due to an infection in the chest (pyothorax or 
mediastinitis) following an esophageal perforation require emergency surgical stenting, 
debridement, or drainage. Option D: The presence of epigastric pain radiating to the shoulders with air under the diaphragm 
point to a diagnosis of abdominal esophagus perforation. It requires immediate surgical 
intervention to restore the integrity of the esophagus. Consideration for interventio 
n in esophageal perforation Indications for non-operative Indications for operative ma 
nagement management Small septic load 
Large septic load Minimal cardiovascular upset

questions.question:
Question 26: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved 
on loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an 
intrathoracic gas bubble. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

options.a: Lump in the throat only felt during swallowing
options.c: Does not interfere with eating or drinking

questions.explanation:
392 
Sold by @itachibot The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a hiatus hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any 
abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the 
hiatus of the diaphragm. Type 1 - sliding hernia: Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra 
abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The 
treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication. Type 2 - rolling hiatus hernia: Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the 
thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus
